{{Infobox musical artist | name = Whistlin' Alex Moore | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Alexander Herman Moore | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date|1899|11|22|mf=y}}
[[Dallas]], [[Texas]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1989|1|20|1899|11|22|mf=y}}
Dallas, Texas | instrument = [[Piano]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Blues]]
[[Boogie-woogie]] | occupation = [[Pianist]], [[singer]], [[songwriter]], [[Whistling|whistler]] | years_active = Early 1920s–1989 | label = [[Arhoolie Records|Arhoolie]], [[Document Records|Document]], [[Rounder Records|Rounder]], [[Columbia Records|Columbia]] | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Whistlin' Alex Moore''' (November 22, 1899 – January 20, 1989){{cite web|author=Jim O'Neal |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/whistlin-alex-moore-mn0000250454 |title=Whistlin' Alex Moore | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1989-01-20 |accessdate=2014-01-31}} was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[pianist]], [[singer]] and [[Whistling|whistler]]. He is best remembered for his recordings of "Across The Atlantic Ocean" and "Black Eyed Peas and Hog Jowls."{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1980.html |title=The 1980s |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2014-01-31}} ==Early life== Born '''Alexander Herman Moore''' in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]],{{cite web|url=http://www.wirz.de/music/moorafrm.htm |title=Whistlin' Alex Moore discography |publisher=Wirz.de |accessdate=2014-01-31}} After his father's death, Moore dropped out of school to support his mother and two siblings. He learned the piano before entering the [[United States Army]] in 1916. His overall sound during the 1920s combined elements of the blues, [[ragtime]], barrelhouse boogie, and [[Stride (music)|stride]]. The same decade saw Moore acquire his [[nickname]], based upon a whistle he made while playing the piano. ==Career== In 1929, he made his debut [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] for [[Columbia Records]]. The [[Gramophone record|records]] he made did not sell in great quantities, and Moore did not record again until 1937, when he issued a few sides on [[Decca Records]]. It was 1951 before Moore recorded again with [[RPM Records (United States)|RPM Records]]/[[Kent Records|Kent]]. However, throughout the 1940s and 1950s, Moore performed in [[nightclub|clubs]] in Dallas and occasionally other parts of Texas. [[Arhoolie Records]] signed him to a [[recording contract]] in 1960, and those subsequent recordings saw him obtain nationwide recognition. Throughout the 1960s, Moore played at clubs and [[music festival|festivals]] in [[United States|America]], as well as a small number of festivals across [[Europe]]. He toured with the [[American Folk Blues Festival]] in 1969, performing on the same bill as [[Earl Hooker]] and [[Magic Sam]]. The same year he recorded a session in [[Stuttgart]], [[Germany]], which led to the release of ''Alex Moore in Europe''. He did not record again in either the 1970s or 1980s, yet continued to give live performances up to his death. He remembered and sang again the blues he had recorded in the 1920s and 1930s, such as "West Texas Woman" and "Blue Bloomer Blues", with their touching and [[poetry|poetic]] [[lyrics]]. In 1987, Moore was granted a [[National Heritage Fellowship]] by the [[National Endowment for the Arts]], becoming the first [[African American]] Texan to receive such an honor. The year before his death, he recorded ''Wiggle Tail,'' his final session for [[Rounder Records]] On November 22, 1988, the state of Texas designated his birthday 'Alex Moore Day.' ==Personal== Moore died of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] in January 1989 in Dallas, aged 89.{{cite web|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fmobh |title=Texas State Historical Association (TSHA) : Moore, Alexander Herman |publisher=Tshaonline.org |date= |accessdate=2014-01-31}} He never married, but was survived by a son and daughter. He was interred at the Lincoln Memorial Cemetery in Dallas. ==Legacy== [[Music journalism|Music journalist]] Tony Russell wrote that "Moore was so odd a performer that some newcomers to the blues have been uncertain whether to take him seriously. By the time he became moderately well-known on the international blues scene of the 1960s and 1970s; his always singular style had burgeoned into florid eccentricity, and he would reminisce tirelessly in a foggy half-shout about youthful high times in his hometown, over skipping blues and [[boogie-woogie]] [[piano]] patterns with occasional bursts of shrill [[whistling]]."{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | pages= 147–148 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} ==Selected discography== *''Wiggle Tail'' (1988) *''Whistlin' Alex Moore'' (1994) *''From North Dallas to the East Side'' (1994) *''Ice Pick Blues'' (1995){{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/whistlin-alex-moore-mn0000250454/discography |title=Whistlin' Alex Moore | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1989-01-20 |accessdate=2014-01-31}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.wirz.de/music/moorafrm.htm Illustrated discography] *[http://www.deadbluesguys.com/dbgtour/moore_alex.htm Grave headstone] *{{findagrave|14621513}} {{Authority control|VIAF=36120800}} {{Persondata | NAME = Moore, Alexander Herman | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = Moore, Whistlin' Alex | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American blues pianist, singer and whistler | DATE OF BIRTH = November 22, 1899 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Dallas, Texas, United States | DATE OF DEATH = January 20, 1989 | PLACE OF DEATH = Dallas, Texas, United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Moore, Whistlin Alex}} [[Category:1899 births]] [[Category:1989 deaths]] [[Category:African-American pianists]] [[Category:American blues pianists]] [[Category:Songwriters from Texas]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:Boogie-woogie pianists]] [[Category:Deaths from myocardial infarction]] [[Category:Musicians from Dallas, Texas]] [[Category:Texas blues musicians]] [[Category:Whistlers]]
